text: Dudes. TNW asks a bunch of (iOS) devs why they don't dev for Android. There is some hot garbage here. "not only is iOS a superior and more expressive platform to build for, but I have a gut feeling that developers who prefer Android and love Java aren’t keeping up with the times or the industry. ... There’s no sense of developer momentum, no sense of deep pride, and it feels like developers only build for Android when they’re forced to." Shots fired. What say you?
<http://thenextweb.com/dd/2015/12/17/reservoir-devs-why-apps-really-hit-ios-before-android/>

attachments.title: Reservoir Devs: Why apps really hit iOS before Android
attachments.text: We asked developers why apps tend to hit iOS before Android. The answers may surprise you.
attachments.fallback: The Next Web: Reservoir Devs: Why apps really hit iOS before Android

text: /gif rude
"developers only build for Android when they're forced to" that might be true at some places but probably not so much of the people in this slack team
there definitely are android devs that "keep up with the times" and just prefer to dev for android
These devs they interviewed seem to have a pretty US-centric view. And the headline is so misleading. It should say, "Why a few random iOS developers I know don't like to make apps for Android."
a couple of them seem to mention the users on iOS tend to spend more... which is true, but I wish it wasn't
<@U0DMFJC0H>: those people just seem to be dicks and think that they're superior. Leave them in their bubble, they're not worth the 'developer' title.
But it does seem like iOS developers seem to dominate the media conversation.
That's mostly because they are the ones crying about other people.
Drama creators, just what the media is looking for.
I wonder if we can't organize a response. Why are you only talking to iOS developers? Why don't you as Android devs why they "really" have issues with iOS?
You know what
I'll write a blog post as a reaction to that post
How ridiculous to keep the developers hidden

<@U0546QERR>: This is interesting: "iPhone shoppers may still convert at higher rates and have a higher average spend than Android phone shoppers, but the gap between the two operating systems is shrinking."
<http://moovweb.com/blog/are-ios-users-still-more-valuable-than-android-users/>

attachments.title: Are iOS Users Still More Valuable Than Android Users?
attachments.text: Though iOS users are still more valuable than Android users, the gap between mobile commerce conversion rates on Android phones and iPhones is now just 5%.
attachments.fallback: Moovweb: Are iOS Users Still More Valuable Than Android Users?
